abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is mixed.
            Implementation of investment and technical assistance
            activities proceeded in a satisfactory manner, albeit
            subject to delays. The power finance corporation's
            business grew and its financial base strengthened. However,
            financial and operating performance of state electricity
            boards remained unsatisfactory despite the operational and
            financial action plan agreements. These are some of the
            learned from this project: The development outcome of Bank
            assistance to India's state power sector will likely be
            unsatisfactory unless sectoral issues on regulation, tariff
            and financial reform, and managerial autonomy are addressed
            through a full restructuring of the sector. Project
            development objectives should be realistic, not wide-ranging
            nor addressed to many sector issues. For complex projects,
            compliance with sub-loan conditions should b sought up-front
            at time of sub-loan approval. Acceptance of revenue
            subsidies in lieu of tariff adjustments greatly hindered
            tariff reform and weakened the utilities' resolve to
            become financially sound and independent. Future Bank
            lending to PFC should be extended only if the beneficiaries
            adopt a reform agenda that the Bank would have otherwise
            required under its current direct lending operations with
            reforming state powers. The financial rate of return of the
            sub-projects should be a primary sub-loan eligibility
            criterion to ensure that financial revenues cover costs.
            Project components should have been trimmed down.
